Introduction

Schizophreniform disorder is a time-limited psychotic disorder characterized by â‰¥2 psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, negative symptoms) that last â‰¥1 month and <6 months.  If symptoms persist beyond 6 months, the diagnosis is changed to schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.

Epidemiology and risk factors



The lifetime prevalence rate of schizophreniform disorder is estimated to be 0.1%.  Prevalence rates are similar in men and women, and symptom onset is typically between late adolescence and early adulthood.



Factors that may contribute to the risk for schizophreniform disorder include genetic (first-degree relative with schizophrenia or psychotic mood disorder) and environmental (eg, low birth weight, adverse childhood event, trauma).

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis of schizophreniform disorder is unclear, although it may be related to glutamatergic signaling disruptions, as well as abnormalities of the prefrontal cortex, parietal cortex, and hippocampus.

Clinical presentation



Schizophreniform disorder includes the same symptoms as schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, negative symptoms), although they tend to be more abrupt in onset and are experienced for a shorter duration (<6 months).



Delusions are fixed, false beliefs that do not change even when met with contradictory evidence.  They can be bizarre and clearly implausible (eg, belief that aliens removed internal organs) or nonbizarre (eg, terrorist group hacked personal laptop).  Varying themes of delusions can include:



  • Persecutory:  belief that one is being harmed or threatened by another person or group
  • Referential:  belief that certain environmental cues or comments are directed at oneself (eg, message on billboard pertains to the individual)
  • Grandiose:  belief that the patient is extraordinary in some way (eg, wealth, fame, abilities)
  • Erotomanic:  false belief that another person is in love with them
  • Somatic:  false belief about health or organ system (eg, patients believe they have leukemia despite normal diagnostic studies)
  • Nihilistic:  belief that oneself or the world does not exist or is on the verge of destruction (eg, individuals believe they are already dead)


Hallucinations are perceptions that are experienced in the absence of an external stimulus and can be associated with any of the senses (eg, auditory, visual, tactile).  Auditory hallucinations are the most common in schizophreniform and primary psychotic disorders and are usually experienced as voices.



Disorganized speech is an observable sign of a thought disorder, which is one of the core symptoms of schizophreniform and schizophrenia.  Examples include:



  • Tangentiality:  Initial response is indirectly related to the question, although the patient shifts to ideas that are increasingly off-topic without returning to the original idea
  • Incoherence (word salad):  response with words and phrases that have no meaning (eg, "They you up me them.")


Grossly disorganized behavior can include unpredictable agitation, intense emotional responses (eg, continuously laughing for no apparent reason), or wearing clothing that is inappropriate for the weather (eg, 4 layers of clothing in extremely hot weather).  Catatonic behaviors can also be seen in schizophreniform disorder and may include mutism, purposeless motor activity, maintenance of abnormal postures, and staring.



Negative symptoms are less common in schizophreniform disorder (when compared to schizophrenia).  They can include diminished emotional expression (decreased eye contact, facial expressions, and/or body movements), alogia (decreased speech output), and avolition (minimal or no participation in purposeful activities such as work or socialization).

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of schizophreniform disorder, the following criteria must be met:



  • â‰¥2 of the following, each present for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated), are present.  At least one of these must be delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized speech:

    • Delusions
    • Hallucinations
    • Disorganized speech
    • Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
    • Negative symptoms
  • An episode of the disorder lasts â‰¥1 month but <6 months.
  • Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out because either:
    • No major depressive or manic episodes have occurred concurrently with the active-phase symptoms OR
    • If mood episodes have occurred during active-phase symptoms, they have been present for a minority of the total duration of the active and residual periods of the illness.
  • The disturbance is not attributable to the physiologic effects of a substance (eg, recreational substances, medication) or another medical condition.


Schizophreniform disorder is often a provisional diagnosis that requires longitudinal monitoring; if symptoms persist for â‰¥6 months, the diagnosis is changed to either schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder (if prominent mood symptoms are also present).

Differential diagnosis



When the differential diagnosis for psychotic symptoms is considered, the duration of symptoms and level of functional impairment are distinguishing factors (

):



  • Brief psychotic disorder:  is also characterized by time-limited delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech; however, the duration of symptoms is shorter, lasting at least 1 day but less than 1 month.
  • Delusional disorder also presents with delusions that can be associated with hallucinations; however, the hallucinations are not prominent and are related only to the delusion.  There are no associated negative symptoms, disorganized speech, or disorganized behaviors.
  • Schizophrenia involves the same set of symptoms as schizophreniform disorder, although the diagnosis must also include significant functional impairment; the duration of symptoms is at least 6 months and the course of illness is chronic.
  • Substance-induced psychotic disorder:  also presents with prominent delusions and/or hallucinations; however, there must be evidence in the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of substance use that is capable of causing psychosis (eg, alcohol withdrawal, amphetamine intoxication).
  • Psychotic disorder due to another medical condition:  also involves hallucinations or delusions; however, clinical findings of a pathophysiologic process known to cause psychosis are identified (eg, multiple sclerosis, traumatic brain injury).

Evaluation and diagnostic work-up



The large overlap of psychotic symptoms with other medical conditions requires a thorough history, physical examination, and diagnostic work-up.



Factors that suggest primary psychotic illness include:



  • Age of onset <40
  • Prodromal period (vs acute onset of symptoms)
  • Auditory hallucinations (vs visual, gustatory, tactile)
  • Family history of psychiatric illness


Laboratory evaluation should include:



  • Chemistry panel to assess for electrolyte and fluid imbalances
  • Complete blood count with differential
  • Liver function tests
  • Thyroid function tests
  • Vitamin B12 level
  • Urine drug screen
  • Urinalysis
  • HIV serology


Further diagnostic evaluation may be indicated depending on the clinical findings:



  • Wilson disease (ataxia, dysarthria, abdominal pain, abnormal liver function testing) (

  • Heavy metal poisoning (cognitive deficits, ataxia, choreoathetosis, polyneuropathy): heavy metal screening
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (arthralgia, photosensitivity, constitutional symptoms) (

  • Seizure activity: electroencephalography
  • Stroke or dementia (focal weakness, cognitive/speech impairment): CT scan of the head, MRI of the brain
  • Autoimmune encephalitis (catatonic symptoms, seizures, cognitive impairment, autonomic instability): antibody testing of cerebrospinal fluid and serum

Management



Schizophreniform disorder is typically a provisional diagnosis (ie, a temporary diagnosis that requires more information).  Longitudinal monitoring is necessary to understand the duration of symptoms and determine a final diagnosis: schizophreniform disorder if the symptoms resolve within 6 months versus schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder if the symptoms persist beyond 6 months.



Because of delusions and hallucinations, especially those that are persecutory in nature, there is a risk for self-harm, agitation, and aggression.  Screening for suicidal and homicidal ideation, assessing risk factors, and planning for safety are necessary to determine an appropriate level of care.  Hospitalization may be required for those at imminent risk of harming themselves or others.



Treatment of schizophreniform disorder includes pharmacotherapy with antipsychotic medication and benzodiazepines if necessary, as well as psychotherapy:



  • Pharmacotherapy:

    • Second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs) (eg, risperidone, aripiprazole) are preferred over first-generation antipsychotics (FGA) (eg, haloperidol).

      • Improved tolerability and risk profile occur with SGAs (relatively decreased risk for extrapyramidal symptoms and tardive dyskinesia)
      • Medication is gradually tapered and discontinued after sustained symptom remission (eg, 1 year); close monitoring for recurrence is necessary
    • Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam) may be necessary for severe agitation/anxiety or if catatonic symptoms are present.
  • Psychotherapy:  Psychotherapy focuses on modalities that are goal-oriented, are structured, and emphasize psychoeducation.  Examples include cognitive-behavioral therapy and family therapy (depending on the age and living situation of the patient).


Schizophreniform disorder can occur with depressive and anxiety symptoms.  Screening and providing appropriate treatment recommendations are necessary.

Prognosis



The prognosis of schizophreniform disorder is variable: Approximately a third of patients experience a full recovery, whereas a majority of the remaining patients develop chronic symptoms consistent with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.  Positive prognostic indicators include acute onset of psychotic symptoms, confusion, high premorbid functioning, absence of blunted or flat affect, and early treatment intervention.

Summary



Schizophreniform disorder involves â‰¥2 psychotic symptomsâ€”delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, negative symptomsâ€”that last â‰¥1 month and <6 months.  Diagnosis is typically provisional; longitudinal monitoring is required to determine whether symptoms resolve within 6 months (schizophreniform disorder) or persist (schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder).  Treatment consists of antipsychotic medication (second-generation antipsychotics) and psychotherapy.
